questions.question: He was tired. He continued to work. (Join with a suitable conjunction)
questions.answer: Although he was tired, he continued to work.
alternatives: He was tired but he continued to work.
He was tired, yet he continued to work.
questions.explanation: 'Although/Though' shows contrast/concession. Despite being tired (unexpected), he still worked. 'But' and 'yet' also show contrast.

questions.question: I stayed at home. It was raining heavily. (Join with a suitable conjunction)
questions.answer: I stayed at home because it was raining heavily.
alternatives: I stayed at home as it was raining heavily.
I stayed at home since it was raining heavily.
questions.explanation: 'Because/as/since' shows cause-effect. The rain (cause) led to staying home (effect).

questions.question: She is intelligent. She is careless at times. (Join with a suitable conjunction)
questions.answer: She is intelligent but careless at times.
alternatives: She is intelligent yet careless at times.
Although she is intelligent, she is careless at times.
questions.explanation: 'But' shows contrast between positive trait (intelligent) and negative trait (careless).

questions.question: Hurry up. We will miss the bus. (Join with a suitable conjunction)
questions.answer: Hurry up, or we will miss the bus.
alternatives: Hurry up, otherwise we will miss the bus.
questions.explanation: 'Or/otherwise' presents a consequence if the action isn't taken. It's a conditional warning.

questions.question: Fill in: Rahul ___ Santosh are best friends.
questions.explanation: 'And' joins two equal subjects. Both Rahul and Santosh together are best friends.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ you work hard, you will not succeed.
questions.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not'. The sentence means: If you don't work hard, you will not succeed.

questions.question: Fill in: I will wait ___ you come back.
questions.explanation: 'Until/till' indicates up to the point when. I will wait up to the time when you return.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ he is rich, he is not happy.
questions.explanation: 'Although/Though' shows concession. Despite being rich (unexpected), he is not happy.

questions.question: Fill in: She failed ___ she worked hard.
questions.explanation: 'Although/though' shows unexpected result. Despite working hard (cause), she failed (unexpected effect).

questions.question: Fill in: I don't know ___ he will come or not.
questions.explanation: 'Whether' or 'if' introduces an indirect yes/no question showing uncertainty.

questions.question: Fill in: Make hay ___ the sun shines.
questions.explanation: 'While' indicates during the time that. This is the proverb meaning to take advantage of opportunities when available.

questions.question: Fill in: He ran fast ___ he could catch the bus.
questions.explanation: 'So that' shows purpose. He ran fast with the purpose/intention of catching the bus.

questions.question: Fill in: I was late ___ my car broke down.
questions.explanation: 'Because/as/since' gives the reason. The car breaking down is the reason for being late.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ had I reached home ___ it started raining.
questions.explanation: 'No sooner...than' is a correlative conjunction showing that one thing happened immediately after another.

questions.question: Fill in: He is ___ a singer ___ a dancer.
questions.explanation: 'Both...and' is a correlative conjunction used to emphasize two things together. He has both qualities.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ you apologize, I will not forgive you.
questions.explanation: 'Unless' means 'if not'. The condition for forgiveness is apologizing.

questions.question: Fill in: She is ___ rich ___ generous.
questions.explanation: 'Not only...but also' emphasizes two qualities. She has both richness and generosity.

questions.question: Fill in: I like tea ___ I don't like coffee.
questions.explanation: 'But' shows contrast between two preferences - liking one thing but not the other.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ it was cold, we went for a swim.
questions.explanation: 'Although/though' shows unexpected action. Despite the cold (unusual), we still went swimming.

questions.question: Fill in: Study hard ___ you will fail.
questions.explanation: 'Otherwise/or/else' shows consequence. If you don't study hard, failure will result.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ you ___ I can solve this problem.
questions.explanation: 'Neither...nor' is a correlative conjunction used to negate both options. Neither person can solve it.

questions.question: Fill in: He came ___ I was leaving.
questions.explanation: 'As/when/while' indicates simultaneous actions. Both events happened at the same time.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ you want tea ___ coffee?
questions.explanation: 'Or' presents a choice between alternatives. It asks which one you prefer.

questions.question: Fill in: She will come ___ she finishes her work.
questions.explanation: 'After/when/once' shows time sequence. She will come following the completion of her work.

questions.question: Fill in: ___ he is poor, he is honest.
questions.explanation: 'Though/Although' shows concession. Despite being poor, honesty is maintained.
